questions.prompt: In BG 6.1, what distinguishes a true sannyasi from one who merely abstains from activities?
choices: Complete withdrawal from all duties and social responsibilities
Performing prescribed duties without attachment to results
Abandoning family life regardless of spiritual advancement
Accepting formal vows and wearing traditional renunciate dress
questions.feedback: Anashritah karma-phalam (unattached to work-fruits) karyam karma karoti (performs required work)-such person is sannyasi and yogi, not one who abandons agni (fire) and kriya (activities). The trap: external renunciation defines spiritual status. Why this matters: The false path is equating renunciation with inactivity-thinking abandoning duties makes one sannyasi, missing consciousness-quality determines status not behavior. Real understanding: True sannyasi/yogi performs full duties without fruit-attachment-internal detachment not external withdrawal. Fire-ceremony cessation doesn't make sannyasi; desireless work-performance does. Therefore cultivate internal renunciation while maintaining external engagement-transformation of consciousness not lifestyle defines authentic spiritual standing.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 6.1, what false path does Srila Prabhupada warn against regarding renunciation?
choices: Abandoning work before purifying consciousness through selfless service
Remaining in household life instead of taking formal sannyasa
Performing duties while maintaining family relationships and obligations
Accepting guidance from spiritual teachers rather than acting independently
questions.feedback: What they call sannyasa (renunciation) know as yoga-na hyasannyasta-sankalpah yogi bhavati (one doesn't become yogi without renouncing sankalpas/desires). The trap: yoga and sannyasa are different paths. Why this matters: The false path is treating yoga-sannyasa as distinct alternatives-missing both require identical internal state: desire-renunciation. Real understanding: Yoga IS sannyasa when properly understood-both mean desire-transcendence enabling Krishna-consciousness. External differences (active vs withdrawn) less significant than internal similarity (desireless). This unifies seemingly divergent paths through consciousness-quality. Therefore don't artificially separate yoga-sannyasa-both achieve same internal state (desire-transcendence) through different external expressions, demonstrating consciousness-primacy over lifestyle-form.

questions.prompt: According to BG 6.2, what is the relationship between yoga and renunciation?
choices: Yoga practice and renunciation are completely separate paths
Renunciation of desire is itself the yoga Krishna describes
Physical yoga postures lead automatically to mental renunciation
Only after renunciation can one begin practicing yoga
questions.feedback: For muni (sage) desiring yoga-aroha (ascending), karma is karanam (means); for one yoga-arudha (ascended), shamah (tranquility) is karanam (means). The trap: single method for all stages. Why this matters: The false path is universal prescription-applying same practice regardless of advancement-level, missing graduated approach necessity. Real understanding: Yogaruruksu (beginner ascending) needs karma-yoga (engaged action) for purification; yogarudha (advanced ascended) needs shama (tranquility) for deepening. Different stages require different approaches-beginners purify through action, advanced stabilize through stillness. This validates developmental spirituality-meet practitioners where they are. Therefore apply stage-appropriate practice-karma-yoga for purification-phase, dhyana-yoga for realization-phase, recognizing spiritual path's progressive nature requiring different methods at different stages.

questions.prompt: In BG 6.3, what distinguishes the beginning practitioner from the advanced yogi?
choices: The beginner uses work without attachment as the means; the advanced has attained cessation
The beginner meditates occasionally during spare time; the advanced meditates constantly
The beginner needs a qualified teacher for guidance; the advanced practices independently
The beginner focuses on ethical behavior; the advanced transcends all moral codes
questions.feedback: When neither sarva-sankalpah (all desires) nor karmashu (in actions) attached-yogarudha (ascended in yoga) is declared. The trap: achievement through effort-cessation. Why this matters: The false path is thinking non-attachment means non-engagement-missing that desire-transcendence enables full action without binding attachment. Real understanding: Yogarudha simultaneously transcends desires AND actions' binding power-not by avoiding but by performing without attachment. Sankalpah (mental formations) and karmashu (activities) both transcended through consciousness-shift not behavior-modification. Therefore aim for engaged transcendence-active participation without volitional investment, achieving freedom through consciousness-quality not activity-quantity reduction.

questions.prompt: According to BG 6.4, when is one said to be established in yoga?
choices: When one masters advanced meditation techniques and physical postures
When one renounces all sense objects and desires for them
When one withdraws from society and lives in complete isolation
When one achieves supernatural powers through yogic practice
questions.feedback: Uddharet atmana atmanam (one should elevate self by self)-atma (self) is both mitra (friend) and vairee (enemy) depending on self-mastery. The trap: external savior dependency. Why this matters: The false path is seeking external rescue-guru/God/circumstances to elevate while remaining passive, missing self-effort necessity. Real understanding: Self must elevate self through disciplined practice-no external agent can substitute for personal striving. Atma becomes friend (when controlled) or enemy (when uncontrolled)-same entity different relationship based on self-governance. This establishes personal responsibility-liberation requires active self-work not passive waiting for external salvation. Therefore engage in vigorous self-improvement-guru guides but individual must do work, God facilitates but won't override free will, taking personal responsibility for spiritual advancement.

questions.prompt: In BG 6.5, how does the mind function as both friend and enemy?
choices: As friend when focused on material success and achievement; as enemy when spiritual
As friend when controlled by purified intelligence; as enemy when left uncontrolled
As friend in youth when sharp and clear; as enemy in old age when becoming dull
As friend when educated through scripture study; as enemy when remaining ignorant
questions.feedback: Self conquered for one who conquered self becomes mitra (friend); for unconquered, self acts as shatru-vat (like enemy) in enmity. The trap: self-acceptance without self-mastery. Why this matters: The false path is unconditional self-embrace-'love yourself as you are' without self-improvement, missing that uncontrolled self creates suffering. Real understanding: Conquered self (controlled through discipline) becomes ally enabling spiritual progress; unconquered self (following every impulse) sabotages spiritual goals like enemy. Not external enemy but internal lack of self-governance. Therefore practice self-control-not self-rejection but self-governance, converting inner chaos into inner ally through disciplined spiritual practice.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 6.5, what psychological trap does Srila Prabhupada identify about the material mind?
choices: The mind can be completely destroyed through intense meditation practice and effort
The uncontrolled mind perpetually seeks sense gratification and drags one down materially
The mind is inherently evil and must be replaced entirely by pure spirit
The mind functions identically for all people regardless of training or purification
questions.feedback: Jitatmanah prashantasya (for self-conquered peaceful one)-same-sighted in sheeta-ushna (cold-heat), sukha-duhkha (pleasure-pain), mana-apamana (honor-dishonor). The trap: stoic emotional flattening. Why this matters: The false path is forced neutrality-suppressing all reactions mechanically, producing brittle equanimity requiring constant vigilance. Real understanding: Natural equanimity from self-conquest-jitatmanah (self-mastered) achieves prashantatva (peace) enabling sama-drishti (equal vision) toward all dualities. Not suppression but transcendence-dualities don't disturb because consciousness anchored beyond their reach. Therefore cultivate self-mastery producing natural peace-enables spontaneous equanimity without forced neutralization, achieving steadiness through spiritual grounding not psychological effort.

questions.prompt: According to BG 6.6, what characterizes one who has conquered the mind versus one who has not?
choices: The conquered mind brings steady self-realization; the unconquered brings struggle
The conquered mind produces supernatural abilities; the unconquered produces weakness
The conquered mind requires no further practice; the unconquered needs constant effort
The conquered mind becomes emotionless; the unconquered remains emotionally reactive
questions.feedback: Jnana-vijnana-trptatma (satisfied by knowledge-realization)-sees sama (equally) loshta-ashma-kanchana (clod-stone-gold). The trap: material value-nihilism. Why this matters: The false path is denying practical distinctions-treating gold and dirt as literally equivalent, missing transcendental vision that sees equal spiritual value beneath functional differences. Real understanding: Yuktatma (established yogi) sees sama not by ignoring differences but by transcending material value-hierarchy-clod/stone/gold differ functionally but equal spiritually as Krishna's energy. Not material leveling but spiritual transcendence. Therefore develop sama-drishti-recognize material varieties' practical utility while transcending attachment-hierarchy, seeing all as Krishna's energy regardless of material value-gradations.

questions.prompt: In BG 6.7, what dualities does the self-realized person transcend?
choices: Knowledge and ignorance, wisdom and complete foolishness
Heat and cold, happiness and distress, honor and dishonor
Rich and poor, healthy and sick, young and old
Success and failure, victory and defeat, gain and loss
questions.feedback: Suhrn-mitra-ari-udasina-madhyastha-dveshya-bandhu-sadhu-api-ca-papesu-sama-buddhih (equal-minded toward friend-enemy-neutral-mediator-hateful-relative-virtuous-sinful)-vishishyate (is distinguished). The trap: relationship-nihilism or naive universalism. Why this matters: The false path is either eliminating all distinctions (everyone equally significant) or maintaining distinctions that produce attachment-aversion, missing transcendental vision maintaining functional roles while transcending emotional reactions. Real understanding: Nine categories of relationships-friend/enemy/neutral/mediator/hateful/relative/virtuous/sinful-all met with sama-buddhi (equal intelligence) by yogi. Not ignoring differences but transcending reactive consciousness-honors functional distinctions (helping sadhu differs from managing papa) without internal turbulence. Therefore practice transcendent pragmatism-maintain appropriate responses to different persons while cultivating equal-minded consciousness underneath varied behaviors.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 6.8, why does Srila Prabhupada warn against merely theoretical knowledge?
choices: Because theoretical knowledge alone without realization is insufficient for liberation
Because reading books distracts from practical meditation and yogic exercises
Because understanding philosophy leads to pride and spiritual arrogance
Because knowledge must be completely abandoned for pure devotional feeling
questions.feedback: Yogi constantly (satatam) should yunjita (engage) citta (consciousness) staying viviktadeshena (in solitary place), yatatma (self-controlled), nirasir (without desires), aparigraha (non-possessive). The trap: occasional practice sufficiency. Why this matters: The false path is part-time spirituality-meditating occasionally while remaining materially absorbed generally, missing consistent practice-requirement. Real understanding: Satatam (constantly) yunjita (should engage)-continuous practice not sporadic attempts. Ekaki (solitary) yatatma (self-controlled) nirasir (without desires) aparigraha (non-possessive)-comprehensive lifestyle supporting continuous practice. Not segmented spirituality (spiritual during meditation, material otherwise) but integrated consciousness. Therefore cultivate continuous practice-not just formal sessions but persistent consciousness-orientation toward Supreme throughout all activities, maintaining spiritual focus as life's constant backdrop.

questions.prompt: In BG 6.9, what quality of vision distinguishes the most elevated person?
choices: Seeing all people as spiritually equal regardless of all external behavior patterns
Equal vision toward the well-wisher, friend, enemy, envious, pious, and sinner equally
Ability to see the aura and spiritual advancement level of all beings
Recognizing one's own superiority while remaining humble externally toward others
questions.feedback: Shucau deshe (in clean place) establishing firm asana (seat)-neither ati-ucchritam (too high) nor ati-nicham (too low). The trap: location/equipment irrelevance or obsession. Why this matters: The false path is either neglecting practical conditions (practicing anywhere in any position) or obsessing over perfect setup (endless preparation without practice)-missing balanced attention to supportive conditions. Real understanding: Practical prerequisites-clean location, stable seat, moderate height-support meditation without guaranteeing it. Too much attention produces distraction through perfectionism; too little produces distraction through discomfort. Therefore establish reasonable practice-conditions-adequate cleanliness/stability/comfort enabling focus without obsessive environment-engineering, balancing external support with internal priority.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 6.10, what false conception of yoga does Srila Prabhupada correct?
choices: That yoga requires expensive equipment and specialized training facilities for practice
That yoga can be practiced successfully in crowded cities with full social engagements
That yoga practice is only for those born in brahminical families and traditions
That yoga produces immediate results without sustained practice over extended time
questions.feedback: Tatraikagram manah kritva (making mind one-pointed there)-controlling citta (consciousness) and indriyas (senses), practice yoga for atma-vishuddhaye (self-purification). The trap: meditation as relaxation technique. Why this matters: The false path is treating meditation as stress-relief-seeking pleasant feelings without transformation, missing purification-purpose. Real understanding: Ekagrata (one-pointedness) with controlled consciousness-senses for atma-vishuddhaye (self-purification)-meditation as spiritual discipline not therapeutic technique. Aim is consciousness-transformation (purifying false ego) not temporary stress-reduction. Therefore approach meditation as purification-practice-tolerating discomfort of confronting conditioned mind, seeking permanent transformation not temporary relief from material pressure.

questions.prompt: According to BG 6.11-12, what are the specific requirements for the yoga seat and practice?
choices: Any comfortable location with cushions and support for extended sitting
A firm seat of kusha grass, deerskin, and cloth in a sacred place
A professionally designed meditation room with proper lighting and temperature
An elevated platform visible to others to inspire collective practice
questions.feedback: Samam kaya-shiro-grivam (body-head-neck evenly aligned) holding acalam (motionless)-practicing brahmacharya (celibacy) with citta (consciousness) on ekam (one) Krishna. The trap: physical posture suffices for meditation. Why this matters: The false path is postural perfection-assuming correct body-alignment produces meditation, missing consciousness-focus primacy. Real understanding: Physical alignment (samam upright posture, acalam stillness) supports but doesn't substitute for mental focus-citta fixed ekam (on one) Krishna. Brahmacharya (celibacy/sense-control) prevents distraction. Posture facilitates but consciousness determines meditation. Therefore maintain proper posture while prioritizing consciousness-discipline-body's stillness supports mind's one-pointedness but can't replace it, physical foundation enabling mental focus.

questions.prompt: In BG 6.13-14, how should the yogi position the body and focus the vision?
choices: Sitting erect with closed eyes, visualizing the transcendental form of the Lord intently
Sitting still with steady body, head, and neck in straight line, gazing at tip
Lying comfortably in shavasana posture while observing the breath flow naturally and easily
Walking meditation while maintaining continuous awareness of each single step taken forward
questions.feedback: Prashanta-atma (peaceful self) vigata-bhih (without fear) brahmachari-vrate sthitah (established in celibacy-vow)-controlling manas (mind), yukta (engaged) asita (should sit) mat-parah (Me as supreme goal). The trap: technique-fetishism divorced from devotion. Why this matters: The false path is mechanical meditation-perfecting technique without devotional consciousness, missing that Krishna as mat-parah (supreme goal) transforms practice from material to transcendental. Real understanding: Prerequisites-prashanta (peace), vigata-bhih (fearlessness), brahmacharya (celibacy), controlled mind-enable mat-parah (Me as supreme) meditation. Techniques serve devotional goal-meditation isn't impersonal mental training but Krishna-connection practice. Therefore infuse technique with devotion-don't separate meditation-mechanics from Krishna-focus, recognizing spiritual practice requires both proper method and devotional consciousness directing method toward Supreme Person.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 6.15, what false conception of yogic perfection does Srila Prabhupada address?
choices: That yogic perfection means developing eight mystic powers and siddhis for material benefit and gain
That perfection requires complete abandonment of all activity and all relationships with others
That yogic trance state alone without devotion guarantees spiritual liberation from material bondage
That perfection comes through physical exercises rather than consciousness purification and transformation
questions.feedback: Yunjann evam (thus engaging) atmanam (self) yogi niyata-manah (controlled mind) shantim (peace) nirvana-paramam (supreme liberation) mat-samstha (abiding in Me) attains. The trap: liberation as cessation. Why this matters: The false path is negative nirvana-understanding liberation as extinction/nothingness, missing positive reality of mat-samstha (abiding in Krishna). Real understanding: Shanti (peace) and nirvana-parama (supreme liberation) defined as mat-samstha (abiding in Me)-not impersonal void but personal relationship with Supreme. Liberation isn't cessation but connection-ending material existence for transcendental existence with Krishna. Therefore seek positive liberation-not nothingness but Krishna-relationship, redefining freedom from absence-of-bondage to presence-of-devotion, transforming liberation from negative to positive concept.

questions.prompt: In BG 6.16, what extremes prevent yoga practice from being successful?
choices: Too much study or complete ignorance of scripture and teachings
Excessive or insufficient eating, sleeping, working, and taking recreation
Too much solitude or constant social engagement with others
Extreme asceticism or complete material indulgence in sense pleasure
questions.feedback: Na ati-ashnatas (not overeating) nor ati-svapnasya (oversleeping) yoga bhavati (becomes), nor ekantam (complete) anashnatah (fasting) nor jagratah (waking). The trap: extremism as spiritual authenticity. Why this matters: The false path is thinking austerity-intensity demonstrates spiritual seriousness-overfasting/undersleeping to prove dedication, missing balance requirement. Real understanding: Yoga requires yukta (balance) not ati (excess)-eating/sleeping/activity/rest all moderated. Neither over-indulgence (ati-ashnatas) nor over-restriction (ekantam anashnatas) supports practice. Extreme austerity appears impressive but undermines sustainability. Therefore practice moderate lifestyle-sufficient eating/sleeping enabling practice without excess/deficiency, recognizing spiritual life requires practical sustainability through balanced habits not impressive extremism producing burnout.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 6.16, what warning does Srila Prabhupada give about false renunciation?
choices: That any eating or sleeping disqualifies one from yoga practice
That artificial fasting and sleep deprivation without purification cause disturbance
That only those born as brahmanas can properly regulate eating and sleeping
That regulated habits are less important than intensity of meditation
questions.feedback: Yuktahara-viharasya (balanced eating-recreation) yukta-ceshtasya (balanced activity) karma-su yukta-svapna-avabodhasya (balanced sleep-waking)-yoga becomes duhkha-ha (destroyer of suffering). The trap: spirituality requires lifestyle-deprivation. Why this matters: The false path is total material rejection-thinking spiritual advancement requires eliminating normal human needs, missing balance-principle enabling sustainable practice. Real understanding: Yukta (balanced) in all domains-eating/recreation/work/sleep-enables yoga destroying duhkha (suffering). Not ascetic deprivation but intelligent moderation-enjoying material necessities without excess. Sustainability through balance. Therefore maintain yukta-ahara-vihara-regulate material life intelligently supporting spiritual practice, avoiding both indulgent excess and ascetic deprivation, achieving sustainable spiritual lifestyle through moderation.

questions.prompt: According to BG 6.17, what is the result of regulated yoga practice?
choices: Development of perfect memory and intellectual capacity
Yoga destroys all material suffering and distress
Gradual reduction in the need for food and sleep
Ability to remain absorbed in trance indefinitely
questions.feedback: When citta (consciousness) niruddham (controlled) sthitah (remains) atmani (in self) eva nispriha (without desires) from sarva-kamat (all material desires)-then yuktah (established) iti ucyate (is said). The trap: temporary meditation-success equals realization. Why this matters: The false path is mistaking meditative states for liberation-achieving temporary concentration and declaring victory, missing permanent transformation requirement. Real understanding: Yukta (established yogi) maintains consciousness sthita (steady) atmani (in self) nispriha (desireless) toward all kamat (desires)-not temporary concentration but stable realization. Occasional meditation-success differs from established transcendence. Therefore aim for stability-not impressive temporary states but consistent consciousness-quality persisting beyond formal practice, measuring progress by baseline consciousness-level not peak meditation-experiences.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 6.18-19, what warning does Srila Prabhupada give about artificial meditation?
choices: That meditation without proper diet and exercise cannot succeed at all
That forcing the mind into silence without proper engagement creates frustration
That meditation should only be attempted in sacred locations with guidance
That modern people lack the genetic capacity for traditional meditation
questions.feedback: Yatha dipo nivata-sthah (as lamp in windless place) na ingate (doesn't flicker)-yoga-yukta (engaged yogi) whose citta (consciousness) controlled practicing atma-yoga (self-meditation). The trap: restless practice equals sincere effort. Why this matters: The false path is accepting meditation-turbulence as normal-mind wandering constantly yet continuing mechanically, missing that steadiness indicates actual progress. Real understanding: Controlled consciousness like lamp in windless place-steady unflickering focus. Metaphor indicates stability-quality not intensity-quantity. Restless struggling differs from steady focus-former indicates insufficient preparation, latter indicates ripening practice. Therefore cultivate steadiness-patient consistent practice developing natural stability, not frantic effort producing temporary concentration followed by collapse, measuring meditation-quality by steadiness not intensity.

questions.prompt: According to BG 6.20-21, how does the perfected yogi experience happiness?
choices: Through continued but purified engagement with material sense objects
In transcendental bliss beyond the senses, perceived through purified intelligence
By remembering past material enjoyments from a detached perspective
Through complete unconsciousness and absence of all perception
questions.feedback: Where citta niruddham (consciousness controlled) yoga-sevatah (through yoga-practice)-where atmanam atmana pashyan (seeing self through self) atmani (in self) tushyati (is satisfied). The trap: external validation defines spiritual success. Why this matters: The false path is measuring advancement through others' recognition-seeking approval/status/reputation, missing self-validation from direct self-realization. Real understanding: Atmana pashyan atmanam (seeing self through self)-self validating through self-perception not external feedback. Atmani tushyati (satisfied in self)-fulfillment from inner realization not outer recognition. This internalization removes spiritual politics. Therefore cultivate self-validation-measure advancement through direct self-perception of consciousness-quality, not through external markers (titles/positions/followers), achieving independence from social validation even within spiritual community.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 6.20-23, what psychological trap does Srila Prabhupada warn about regarding happiness?
choices: Seeking happiness through external achievements and acquisitions
Believing that material happiness and spiritual happiness are equivalent
Pursuing yoga for mystic powers rather than divine realization
Thinking happiness comes through suppression of all desires
questions.feedback: Sukham atantikam (unlimited happiness) that buddhi-grahyam (intelligence grasps) atindriyam (beyond senses)-established knowing this na chalati (doesn't deviate) from tattvatah (from truth). The trap: sense-based happiness pursuit within spirituality. Why this matters: The false path is seeking pleasant sensory experiences through spiritual practice-sublime feelings/visions/experiences-remaining on indriya (sense) platform though religiously. Real understanding: Atindriyas sukham (transcendental happiness) buddhi-grahyam (grasped by purified intelligence)-beyond sense-perception. Atantikam (unlimited/permanent) versus indriya-sukham (sense-based pleasure) which is anta-vantam (limited/temporary). Established in this tattvatah (truth) na chalati (doesn't waver). Therefore transcend spiritual hedonism-seeking permanent transcendental realization not temporary sublime experiences, elevating spiritual aspiration beyond subtle sense-gratification to actual transcendence.

questions.prompt: According to BG 6.24, what must accompany yoga practice for it to succeed?
choices: Natural talent and favorable birth in a spiritually advanced family
Uncompromising determination and complete mental renunciation of desires born of speculation
Supernatural faith and belief in miraculous divine intervention without effort
Advanced intellectual understanding of all yogic philosophy and techniques
questions.feedback: Gaining which na aparam (no other) gain considers punyasam (greater)-established in which na duhkhena guruna api (not by heavy sorrow) vicalyate (is shaken). The trap: conditional spiritual commitment. Why this matters: The false path is commitment contingent on favorable circumstances-practicing when convenient, abandoning when difficult-missing unwavering establishment requirement. Real understanding: Having gained Krishna-connection considers it param labham (supreme gain)-nothing superior exists. Therefore na vicalyate (unshaken) guruna duhkhena api (even by heavy sorrow)-commitment persists through adversity. This unconditional dedication distinguishes authentic from superficial spirituality. Therefore develop unwavering commitment-establish Krishna-connection as non-negotiable life-priority maintained through favorable/unfavorable circumstances equally, testing spiritual maturity through adversity-persistence not prosperity-enthusiasm.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 6.25, what false expectation does Srila Prabhupada correct about mind control?
choices: That the mind can be controlled quickly through weekend retreats
That mind control develops gradually through patient practice, not suddenly
That only renunciates in monasteries can achieve mental steadiness
That the mind remains perpetually uncontrollable in the material world
questions.feedback: Duhkha-samyoga-viyogam (severing sorrow-connection) yoga-samjnita (called yoga)-practice with nishcayena (determination) yoga without sannyasa vishada (abandoning sad-heartedness). The trap: spiritual passivity or emotionalism. Why this matters: The false path is either mechanical practice without conviction or emotion-driven inconsistency-both missing nishcayena (determined/decisive) requirement. Real understanding: Yoga defined as duhkha-samyoga-viyoga (disconnecting from suffering)-requires nishcayena (firm determination) without vishada (sad-heartedness/depression). Not grim determination but joyful resolve-enthusiasm without emotionalism. Therefore cultivate determined consistency-neither passive compliance nor emotional fluctuation, maintaining steady committed practice through clear conviction producing sustainable spiritual momentum.

questions.prompt: According to BG 6.26, what should one do when the mind wanders during meditation?
choices: Accept the distraction as natural and observe without making any judgment
Bring the mind back under control and fix it steadily on the Supreme
Pause the practice session and return when concentration naturally improves
Analyze carefully why the mind wandered to prevent all future occurrences
questions.feedback: Sankalpa-prabhavan kaman (desires born from sankalpa-mental formations) tyaktva sarvan (abandoning all) asheshatah (completely)-restraining indriya-gramam (sense-group) manasa (by mind) from sarvatah (all sides). The trap: suppression without transformation. Why this matters: The false path is external control while desires persist-restraining behavior without addressing root sankalpa (mental formations), producing forced compliance not genuine transcendence. Real understanding: Address sankalpa-prabhavan (desire-source)-mental formations generating desires-not just controlling expressions. Tyaktva sarvan asheshtah (abandon completely without remainder)-thorough not superficial. Manasa (through mind) control indriya-gramam (sense-group)-mind-level work enabling sense-level control. Therefore work at root-level-transform sankalpa (mental formations) generating desires, not just restrain indriyas (senses) expressing desires, achieving genuine transformation not forced suppression.

questions.prompt: How do BG 6.30-32 synthesize the vision of the perfected yogi regarding the Self and others?
choices: Seeing the individual soul's independence while respecting diversity in paths
Perceiving the Supersoul in all beings and treating all suffering as oneself
Recognizing gradations of spiritual advancement among all practitioners
Understanding the ultimate illusion of all individual existence in matter
questions.feedback: Shanai-shanai (gradually) uparamet (should cease) buddhi-dhrita-grihtaya (by intelligence held firmly)-fixing manas (mind) on atman (self) na kinchit api cintayet (should think nothing else). The trap: instant enlightenment expectation. Why this matters: The false path is expecting immediate transformation-demanding instant liberation producing frustration when progress is gradual, missing patience requirement. Real understanding: Shanai-shanai (gradually/slowly) approach-reasonable expectations preventing discouragement. Buddhi-dhrita (firmly grasped intelligence) guiding process-patient intelligent progression. Uparamet (cessation of material engagement) happens progressively not instantly. Therefore accept gradual development-measure progress over months/years not days/weeks, maintaining patient consistent practice without frustration from immediate-result expectations, trusting process over time.
